title: How do you even begin long-term planning? Feeling lost.

posts.body:
My mother was diagnosed with early-stage Alzheimer's two weeks ago. I've been walking around in a fog ever since.

The neurologist said we should "get our affairs in order" while she still has capacity to make decisions. Then he handed us a pamphlet and we left. That's it. That's all the guidance we got.

I'm the oldest of three kids. My brother lives across the country. My sister is in the middle of a divorce. Everyone's looking at me to figure this out.

I don't even know what questions to ask. Legal stuff? Financial stuff? What about when she gets worse? What do people even plan for?

I've been Googling at 2am and just getting more overwhelmed. Where do I actually start?

Steve, I was exactly where you are three years ago. Here's what I wish someone had told me:

LEGAL - Do these NOW while she has capacity:
- Power of Attorney for finances (who can manage her money when she can't)
- Healthcare Power of Attorney (who makes medical decisions when she can't)
- Living Will / Advance Directive (what does she want regarding end-of-life care)
- HIPAA authorization (who can access her medical info)

Find an elder law attorney. Yes it costs money. It's worth it.

FINANCIAL - Start now, figure out more over time:
- What are her assets and income?
- How will care be paid for?
- Learn about Medicaid (there's a 5-year lookback for eligibility, so decisions now matter)

CARE PLANNING - This evolves:
- Who will be primary caregiver?
- What does she want as things progress?
- At what point would she consider outside help? A facility?

It's overwhelming. Don't try to do it all at once. But the legal stuff is urgent because capacity can change.

Adding to Christine's excellent list:

HAVE THE HARD CONVERSATIONS NOW. While your mom can still participate in decisions, ask her what she actually wants. Does she want to stay home as long as possible? Would she prefer a facility at some point? What matters most to her about quality of life?

These conversations are difficult. My mom cried. I cried. But I'm so grateful now to know what she would have wanted.

ALSO: Include your siblings. I know your sister is going through a divorce and your brother is far away, but caregiving destroys families when people don't communicate. Have a meeting—video call is fine—about expectations and roles. Who can do what? Who can contribute financially? Get it out in the open early.

The Alzheimer's Association has free resources and support groups. You don't have to figure this out alone.

Thank you both. This is the first time since the diagnosis that I've felt like there's actually a path forward instead of just panic.

The legal stuff makes sense to prioritize. I'll look for elder law attorneys this week.

The conversation with Mom about what she wants... that's going to be hard. She's still processing the diagnosis herself. She keeps saying "maybe the doctors are wrong." But you're right that we need to have it before we can't.

The sibling meeting is overdue. We've all been avoiding it because it's uncomfortable. But I can already see the potential for resentment building.

Is there a resource on Kindred specifically about the legal and financial stuff? I saw someone mention it but want to find it.

Yes! Check out https://kindred.app/resources/legal-financial-planning — it covers the documents and financial planning in detail.

For understanding what to expect with Alzheimer's and daily care as things progress, there's https://kindred.app/resources/dementia-care-daily-routines

On the conversation with your mom: her denial is normal. It might take multiple conversations. You don't have to get everything resolved at once. Just start.

Also consider finding a support group specifically for early-stage families. The concerns at this point are different from later stages, and it helps to talk to people in the same boat.

Steve, I want to add one thing that people don't say often enough:

Start taking care of yourself now. Not later when you're exhausted. Now.

Caregiver burnout sneaks up. It starts with missing your own doctor appointments, skipping exercise, saying no to friends. Then suddenly you're depleted and can't give anymore.

Build in boundaries and self-care from the beginning. It's not selfish—it's what lets you keep doing this over the long haul.

You're handling this well by asking for help early. A lot of families wait until crisis.

Thank you all. I feel less panicked. I have a starting point now:

1. Find an elder law attorney (this week)
2. Read those Kindred resources
3. Schedule a family video call (dreading it but it needs to happen)
4. Start the conversation with Mom about her wishes (when the timing feels right)
5. Look into support groups

Sally, you're right about the self-care. I've already been canceling things to "deal with this." I need to be careful about that.

I'll check back in as things progress. Really grateful this community exists.

Steve, just checking in—how did the family call go? And did you find an attorney?

No pressure to answer if you're not ready. Just wanted you to know we're here.

This stuff is hard. Take it one step at a time.
